children.desc: The punishment treatment

The baseline treatment. This is the treatment compared against any treatment coded as punishment treatment (= 1 identifies the punishment effect). This means that the treatment is equal to the punishment treatment, except for the availability of punishment (which includes other concepts that are part of punishment, such as punishment effectiveness, etc.)
Is not a punishment treatment. This is any treatment that is neither a punishment treatment nor a baseline relative to the punishment treatment (In practice, these are ignored in the platform)

children.name: Simultaneous
children.desc: Players make the punishment decision at the same time (i.e., without receiving information about others' punishment decisions on that trial)

children.name: Sequential turn-taking
children.desc: Each player makes a punishment decision in turn

children.name: Sequential leadership-by-example
children.desc: In a game with leadership by example, there is a single privileged player that makes a punishment decision before all others

children.name: Deductive
children.desc: The amount deducted from the account of a punished participant is destroyed

children.name: Redistributive
children.desc: The amount deducted from the account of a punished participant is redistributed to some or all of the other participants in the game

children.name: Monetary
children.desc: An amount of money often converted from game points

children.name: Non-monetary Social
children.desc: Participants receive social incentives, such as blame or praise, from others based on the outcomes of the game

children.name: Hypothetical
children.desc: Hypothetical value for participants (e.g., points)

children.name: Non-monetary Material
children.desc: Amount of other resources (e.g., candies, school supplies)

children.name: Peer
children.desc: Other participants of the same role

children.name: Institution
children.desc: Institutional mechanism inside (e.g., impersonal sanctioning system) or outside (e.g., public institutions like government)

children.name: Network
children.desc: A peer in a game with network structure

children.name: Other
children.desc: Other agent types not included in the current categories

children.name: Leader
children.desc: A participant with some form of higher, relative social power; see Power

children.name: Third Party
children.desc: A person who does not interact with the participants in the main game e.g., a third-party punisher

children.name: Experimenter
children.desc: The person in charge of running the experiment (e.g., principle investigator, research assistant)

children.name: Computer
children.desc: Computerized opponent, and players were informed to be interacting with a computer

children.name: Contribution-based
children.desc: Players who made a contribution less (or more) than a specified amount are punished

children.name: Rank-based
children.desc: The n lowest- (or highest-) ranked players are punished

children.name: Random
children.desc: Random players are punished

children.name: Outcome-based
children.desc: Some set of players is punished if a collective threshold is (not) reached

children.name: Other
children.desc: Other punishment rule

children.name: None
children.desc: No punishment rule

children.name: Focal participant has punished
children.desc: Whether the focal participant punished another player in the previous round. TRUE = Focal participant punished another player in the previous round, FALSE = Focal participant did not punish another player in the previous round.

children.name: Lottery punishment incentive
children.desc: Whether there was a chance of lottery for punishment to be enforced (see lottery incentive). TRUE = A lottery was implemented for punishment to be enforced, FALSE = A lottery was not implemented for punishment to be enforced.

children.name: Punishment effectiveness
children.desc: The ratio of the cost of punishment for the participant who decides to punish, to the cost of punishment for the participant who receives the punishment (e.g., if punishment costs 1 point to inflict a cost of 3 points, = .33).

children.name: Punishment iterations
children.desc: The number of iterations of punishment per punishment phase.

children.name: Punishment probability
children.desc: The probability that a punishment decision is meted out (and thus becomes costly to the punished agent).

children.name: Social value orientation
children.desc: Dispositional weights individuals assign to their own and to othersâ outcomes in interdependent situations (Kuhlman, Camac, & Cunha, 1986; McClintock, 1972)

children.name: Trust propensity
children.desc: A personâs general willingness to trust others (Mayer, Davis, & Schoorman, 1995, p. 714) [based on] expectation of partnerâs goodwill and benign intent (Yamagishi & Yamagishi, 1994, p. 131)

children.name: Self-control
children.desc: The ability to override or change oneâs inner responses, as well as to interrupt undesired behavioral tendencies (such as impulses) and refrain from acting on them (Tangney, Baumeister, & Boone, 2004, p. 274)

children.name: Concern for others
children.desc: Individual differences in the extent to which [â¦] other peopleâs interests serve as guides for behavior (Gerbasi & Prentice, 2013, p. 495)

children.name: Cognitive ability
children.desc: One's general mental capability involving reasoning, problem solving, planning, abstract thinking, complex idea comprehension, and learning from experience (Gottfredson, 1997)

children.name: Risk-taking
children.desc: Oneâs general degree of comfort with facing uncertain gains or losses (Ehrlich & Maestas, 2010, p. 658)

children.name: Risk-taking (behavioral measure)
children.desc: Risk-taking preferences are measured by participants  making a choice between options that involve probabilisic outcomes.

children.name: Individualism
children.desc: Individualists will see themselves as more differentiated and separate from others, and place more importance on asserting their individuality (Bochner, 1994, p. 274)

children.name: Extraversion
children.desc: [Individual differences in] engagement in social endeavors (such as socializing, leading, or entertaining) (Ashton & Lee, 2007, p. 156)

children.name: Conscientiousness
children.desc: The proactive side of Conscientiousness is seen most clearly in the need for achievement and commitment to work; the inhibitive side is seen in moral scrupulousness and cautiousness (Costa et al., 1991, p. 889)

children.name: Openness to experience
children.desc: [Individual differences in] engagement in idea-related endeavors (such as learning, imagining, and thinking) (Ashton & Lee, 2007, p. 156)

children.name: Collectivism
children.desc: Oneâs tendency to give priority to the collective self over the private self, especially when these two come into conflict (Yamagishi, Kuhlman, & Sugimori, 1995, p. 659)

children.name: Competitiveness
children.desc: Individualsâ desire to do better than others, their desire to win in interpersonal situations, and their enjoyment of interpersonal competition (Houston, McIntire, Kinnie, & Terry, 2002, p. 286)

children.name: Agreeableness (FFM)
children.desc: [Individual] differences in the motivation to cooperate (vs. acting selfishly) in resource conflicts (Denissen & Penke, 2008, p. 1285)

children.name: Psychopathy
children.desc: A personality trait characterized by enduring antisocial behavior, diminished empathy and remorse, and disinhibited or bold behavior (Muris et al., 2017, p. 184)

children.name: Neuroticism
children.desc: A broad domain of negative affect, including predispositions to experience anxiety, anger, depression, shame, and other distressing emotions (Costa, Terracciano, & McCrae, 2001, p. 322)

children.name: Machiavellianism
children.desc: A duplicitous interpersonal style, characterized by a cynical disregard for morality and a focus on self-interest and personal gain (Muris et al., 2017, p. 184)

children.name: Right-wing authoritatianism
children.desc: Opposing any change in the social status quo, [â¦] favouring tough punishment of deviance, nonconformity, or innovation, [and] favouring traditional, old-fashioned lifestyles, behavioural norms, and values (Duckitt, Bizumic, Krauss, & Heled, 2010, p. 691)

children.name: Honesty-humility
children.desc: The tendency to be fair and genuine in dealing with others, in the sense of cooperating with others even when one might exploit them without suffering retaliation (Ashton & Lee, 2007, p. 156)

children.name: Agreeableness (HEXACO)
children.desc: The tendency to be forgiving and tolerant of others, in the sense of cooperating with others even when one might be suffering exploitation by them (Ashton & Lee, 2007, p. 156)

children.name: Emotionality
children.desc: Tendencies relevant to the construct of kin altruism [...], including not only empathic concern and emotional attachment toward close others (who tend to be oneâs kin) but also the harm-avoidant and help-seeking behaviors that are associated with investment in kin (Ashton & Lee, 2007, p. 156)

children.name: Self-presentation
children.desc: The extent to which individuals can and do monitor their self-presentation, expressive behavior, and non-verbal affective display (Snyder, 1974, pp. 526/527), [potentially motivated by] the identity concern of oneâs [â¦] evaluation (De Cremer & Tyler, 2005, p. 121)

children.name: Social desirability
children.desc: Tendency to provide answers that are considered socially acceptable in order to present themselves in a favorable light

children.name: Altruism
children.desc: A disposition that leads people who have more of it to be more compassionate and caring toward others in distress (Batson, Bolen, Cross, & Neuringer-Benefiel, 1986, p. 212)

children.name: Inequality aversion
children.desc: [Individual differences in] perceptions of and reactions to observed [â¦] or committed injustice (Schmitt, Baumert, Gollwitzer, & Maes, 2010, p. 212); an individual is inequity averse if he dislikes outcomes that are perceived as inequitable (Fehr & Schmidt, 1999, p. 820).

children.name: Reflective thinking style
children.desc: Reliance on and enjoyment of thinking in an analytical, logical manner [and] a high level of ability to think logically and analytically (Pacini & Epstein, 1999, p. 974).

children.name: Social dominance orientation
children.desc: Individual differences in the preference for group based hierarchy and inequality (Ho et al., 2015, p. 1003)

children.name: Anxiety
children.desc: The stable tendency to attend to, experience, and report negative emotions such as fears, worries, and anxiety across many situations (Gidron, 2013, p. 1989)

children.name: Approach
children.desc: Proneness to engage in goal-directed efforts and to experience positive feelings when the person is exposed to cues of impending reward (Carver & White, 1994, p. 319)

children.name: Achievement
children.desc: Recurrent concern with a standard of excellence and the disposition to derive satisfaction from the mastery of challenging tasks (SchÃ¶nbrodt & Gerstenberg, 2012, p. 726)

children.name: Forgiveness
children.desc: Disposition to forgive interpersonal transgressions over time and across situations (Berry, Worthington, OâConnor, Parrott, & Wade, 2005, p. 183)

children.name: Self-esteem
children.desc: Individual differences in the evaluation of oneâs self-worth and self-respect (Gnambs, Scharl, & Schroeders, 2018, p. 14)

children.name: SVO consistency
children.desc: Consistency in the choice pattern with which SVO is measured

children.name: Positive reciprocity
children.desc: Positive reactions to positively valued behaviours with the emphasis on rewarding someone elseâs behaviour (Perugini, Gallucci, Presaghi, & Ercolani, 2003, p. 274)

children.name: Negative affect
children.desc: Individual differences in the tendency to experience negative moods and feelings, including sadness, worry, and anger (Stanton & Watson, 2014, p. 556)

children.name: Avoidance
children.desc: Sensitivity to the presence or absence of negative outcomes [and] vigilant avoidance of losses or failures (Lockwood, Jordan, & Kunda, 2002, p. 854)

children.name: Envy
children.desc: [Tendency to experience a] sense of inferiority [â¦ and] ill will, frustration, and a subjective sense of injustice prompted by unflattering comparison (Smith, Parrott, Diener, Hoyle, & Kim, 1999, p. 1010). For coding: Justice sensitivity (victim perspective subscale has to be coded as envy)

children.name: Life history strategy
children.desc: Different allocation decisions to the various activities that comprise the life cycle between current and future reproduction, between quality and quantity of offspring, andâin sexual speciesâbetween mating and parenting effort (Del Giudice, 2014)

children.name: Narcissism
children.desc: A grandiose view of the self, a strong sense of entitlement and superiority, a lack of empathy, and a need for social admiration, as well as tendencies to show dominant, charming, bragging, impulsive, and aggressive behaviors (Back et al., 2013, p. 1014)

children.name: Self-efficacy
children.desc: People's beliefs in their ability to influence events that affect their lives (Bandura, 2010)

children.name: Integrity
children.desc: Integrity involves honesty, trustworthiness, fidelity in keeping oneâs word and obligations, and incorruptibility, or an unwillingness to violate principles regardless of the temptations, costs, and preferences of others (Schlenker, 2008, p. 1081)

children.name: Locus of control
children.desc: The degree to which persons expect that a reinforcement or an outcome of their behavior is contingent on their own behavior or personal characteristics versus the degree to which persons expect that the reinforcement or outcome is a function of chance, luck, or fate, is under the control of powerful others, or is simply unpredictable (Rotter, 1990, p. 489)

children.name: Guilt proneness
children.desc: Predisposition to experience negative feelings about personal wrongdoing, even when the wrongdoing is private (T. R. Cohen, Panter, & Turan, 2012, p. 355)

children.name: Emotional intelligence
children.desc: Extent to which [individuals] attend to, process, and utilize affect-laden information of an intrapersonal (e.g., managing oneâs own emotions) or interpersonal (e.g., managing othersâ emotions) nature (Petrides & Furnham, 2006, p. 553)

children.name: Sadism
children.desc: The term sadistic personality describes a person who humiliates others, shows a longstanding pattern of cruel or demeaning behavior to others, or intentionally inflicts physical, sexual, or psychological pain or suffering on others in order to assert power and dominance or for pleasure and enjoyment (OâMeara, Davies, & Hammond, 2011, p. 523)

children.name: Aggression
children.desc: Trait aggressiveness [â¦] identifies people who are prone to hostile cognitions and angry affect as well as a readiness to engage in physical and verbal aggression (Bettencourt, Talley, Benjamin, & Valentine, 2006, p. 752)

children.name: Greed
children.desc: An insatiable desire for more resources, monetary or other (Krekels & Pandelaere, 2015, p. 225)

children.name: Empathy
children.desc: Reactions of one individual to the observed experiences of others (Davis, 1983, p. 113)

children.name: Positive affect
children.desc: Individual differences in the tendency to experience positive emotions and feeling states (Stanton & Watson, 2014, p. 556)

children.name: Trust in self
children.desc: Beliefs about the trust that others have in themselves

children.name: Tolerance for ambiguity
children.desc: Desire for 'an answer on a given topic, any answer [â¦] compared to confusion and ambiguity (Kruglanski, 1990; p. 337)

children.name: Power
children.desc: Desire for power and a drive to come out on top in a status hierarchy (Grina, Bergh, Akrami, & Sidanius, 2016, p. 114)

children.name: Intuitive thinking style
children.desc: Reliance on and enjoyment of feelings and intuitions in making decisions [and] a high level of ability with respect to oneâs intuitive impressions and feelings (Pacini & Epstein, 1999, p. 974)

children.name: Shame proneness
children.desc: High shame-prone individuals attribute transgressions and negative outcomes to characterological faults, experiencing global feelings of self-debasement and enduring negative affect (Thompson, Altmann, & Davidson, 2004, p. 613)

children.name: Victimization
children.desc: Individuals who are a frequent target of aggressions

children.name: Affiliation
children.desc: [Desire] to establish and/or maintain warm and friendly interpersonal relations (French & Chadwick, 1956, p. 296)

children.name: Impulsivity
children.desc: Tendency to deliberate less than most people of equal ability before taking action (Dickman, 1990, p. 95)

children.name: Belief in a just world
children.desc: [Individualsâ tendency] to believe that they live in a world where people generally get what they deserve (Lerner & Miller, 1978, p. 1030)

children.name: Optimism
children.desc: Generalized expectations of the occurrence of good outcomes in oneâs life (Scheier & Carver, 1985, p. 239)

children.name: Pro-environmentalism
children.desc: The collection of beliefs, affect, and behavioral intentions a person holds regarding environmentally related activities or issues (Schultz, Shriver, Tabanico, & Khazian, 2004, p. 31)

children.name: Prosocial
children.desc: Prosocials aim to equalize and/or maximize joint outcomes

children.name: Proself
children.desc: Individualists (who aim to maximize their own outcomes, regardless of the othersâ outcomes) and competitors (who aim to maximize the relative difference between their own and the othersâ outcomes) are often combined in a proself category

children.name: Individualist
children.desc: Individualists aim to maximize their own outcomes, regardless of the othersâ outcomes

children.name: Competitor
children.desc: Competitors aim to maximize the relative difference between their own and the othersâ outcome

children.name: Altruist
children.desc: Altruists are more concerned with a positive outcome for others than for themselves (Bogaert, Boone, & Declerck, 2008)

children.name: Unclassified
children.desc: Participants could not be classified into any of the SVO types. It is common when using triple dominance measures.

children.name: High
children.desc: Participants were classified as high according to the specific individual difference

children.name: Low
children.desc: Participants were classified as low according to the specific individual difference

children.name: Medium
children.desc: Participants were classified as medium according to the specific individual difference

children.name: Control
children.desc: Control group that does not present the disorder under investigation

children.name: Depression
children.desc: Experience of persistent feelings of sadness and hopelessness and lose interest in activities they once enjoyed.

children.name: Schizophrenia
children.desc: Condition characterized by presence of hallucinations, delusions, and disordered thinking and behavior that impairs daily functioning, among other symptoms

children.name: Autism spectrum disorders
children.desc: Deficits in social-emotional reciprocity, nonverbal communicative behaviors used for social interaction, and in developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships.

children.name: Stress
children.desc: Experience of being over-aroused, tense, unable to relax touchy, easily upset, irritable, easily startled nervy, jumpy, fidgety, intolerant of interruption or delay (Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995)

children.name: Bipolar
children.desc: Group of brain disorders that cause extreme fluctuation in a personâs mood, energy, and ability to function (DSM-5)

children.name: Non-suicidal self-injury
children.desc: Deliberate destruction of one's body in the absence of intent to die (e.g., cutting, burning, or hitting oneself)

children.name: Borderline
children.desc: Diagnosed on the basis of a pervasive pattern of instability of interpersonal relationships, self-image, and affects, and marked impulsivity beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts (DSM-5)

children.name: Suicide attempt
children.desc: Individuals who attempted suicide

children.name: Individual difference measure
children.desc: The questionnaire used to measure the individual differences variable.

children.name: Subscale
children.desc: Indicates whether the specific effect size of the Individual difference is calculated based on scores in a specific subscale. TRUE = The specific effect size of the Individual difference is calculated based on scores in a specific subscale, FALSE = The specific effect size of the Individual difference is not calculated based on scores in a specific subscale.

children.name: Common
children.desc: The participant and their partner know each others' group membership

children.name: Unilateral
children.desc: The participant knows their partner's group membership, but not vice-versa

children.name: Unknown
children.desc: Neither the participant or their partner know each others' group membership

children.name: Experimentally induced group
children.desc: An experimentally induced group (e.g., minimal group paradigm)

children.name: Natural group
children.desc: A naturally occurring group (e.g., political partisans, nationalities)

children.name: Ingroup
children.desc: Partner(s) is a member of the participant's group

children.name: Stranger
children.desc: Participants are not informed about whether their partner is an ingroup or outgroup member

children.name: Outgroup
children.desc: Partner(s) is a member of a different group than the participant

children.name: Ingroup and Outgroup
children.desc: When an experimental treatment explicitly provides information that a partner or group belongs to both an ingroup and an outgroup

children.name: Low
children.desc: Participant's identification with their partner is low

children.name: High
children.desc: Participant's identification with their partner is high

children.name: Medium
children.desc: Participant's identification with their partner is medium

children.name: Low
children.desc: Participants were classified as having low levels of entitativity

children.name: High
children.desc: Participants were classified as having high levels of entitativity

children.name: Medium
children.desc: Participants were classified as having medium levels of entitativity

children.name: Entitativity
children.desc: Correlation between cooperation and self-reported perception that the group is an entity (e.g., similarity and interdependence)(Gaertner & Schopler, 1998).

children.name: Identification
children.desc: Correlation between extent to which the participants identify with their partner(s) and cooperation.

children.name: M
children.desc: Male

children.name: F
children.desc: Female

children.name: Heterogeneous gender
children.desc: Whether groups had a mixed gender composition (both males and women). TRUE = Groups had a mixed gender composition (both males and women), FALSE = Groups had a homogeneous gender composition (only males or only women).

children.name: Partner's gender is known
children.desc: Whether participants were aware of the gender of their partner(s). TRUE = Participants were aware of the gender of their partner(s), FALSE = Participants were not aware of the gender of their partner(s).

children.name: K index
children.desc: For 2-persons PDG, it is calculated as (R-P)/(T-S), and 0 < K < 1.

children.name: Other
children.desc: None of the conflict index categories apply

children.name: b/c ratio
children.desc: Ratio between the cost c paid by a cooperator, and the correspondent benefit b received by the partner

children.name: g index
children.desc: Index that identifies the strength of the underlying structural impetus toward cooperation or competition in repeated, multitrial PD tasks with probabilistic endpoints. Their expected gain index, g = (1/(1 - p)][R - T + p(T -P)], where p is the probability that play will continue (Bettenhausen & Murnighan, 1991)

children.name: r index
children.desc: It is calculated as (RâS) / [(RâS) + (TâP)] (Au et al., 2012)

children.name: R' index
children.desc: It is calculated as (R-S)/(T-S)

children.name: S/T ratio
children.desc: It is calculated as the index log (T-S)/(R-P)

children.name: Index of correspondence
children.desc: It is calculated as the correlation between the row and the column playersâ outcomes

children.name: K*-index
children.desc: For N-persons PDG, it is calculated as (A(n)-B(0))/(0(max)-0(min)), and 0 < K < 1

children.name: Average advantage of competition
children.desc: It is calculated as (T+P)/2-(R+S)/2

children.name: Index of competitive advantage
children.desc: It is calculated as S-T

children.name: High
children.desc: High relative level of the specific conflict index

children.name: Low
children.desc: Low relative level of the specific conflict index

children.name: Medium
children.desc: Medium relative level of the specific conflict index

children.name: Ongoing
children.desc: Participants could communicate before multiple (all, or at least several) trials (If the game was one-shot, then communication was coded as ongoing)

children.name: One-shot
children.desc: Participants could only communicate once, before the first trial of the game

children.name: Written
children.desc: Participants could communicate via written messages (either using free text entry or pre-written messages)

children.name: Verbal
children.desc: Participate could speak to each other, either in person or via phone/voice chat

children.name: Nonverbal
children.desc: Other modes of communication, including nonverbal eye gaze, touch, and sound

children.name: Promise
children.desc: Promises (e.g., of own cooperation or reward)

children.name: Other
children.desc: Other content of messages

children.name: Irrelevant
children.desc: Messages irrelevant to the game

children.name: Request
children.desc: Requests and suggestions (e.g., to cooperate or contribute)

children.name: Threat
children.desc: Threats (e.g., of non-cooperation or punishment)

children.name: nan
children.desc: If communication was not restricted, communication content is not coded.

children.name: Optional communication
children.desc: Whether participants had a choice to communicate (or not) with their partner. TRUE = Optional communication, FALSE = Mandatory communication.

children.name: Real communication
children.desc: Whether the communication received by participants was real or fake. TRUE = Real communication, FALSE = Fake communication.

children.name: Communication treatment
children.desc: Whether communication was allowed between participants in the game. TRUE = Participants could communicate in the game, FALSE = Participants could not communicate in the game.

children.name: Restricted communication
children.desc: Whether communication is restricted to pre-specified messages, or participants are free to formulate their own messages. TRUE = Communication restricted to pre-specified messages, FALSE = Free communication.

children.name: individual
children.desc: The decision maker is a single individual. Individuals make a single decision, to be then matched with others in the game, producing an outcome for all participants involved (e.g., each person making a decision in a 4-persons PGD)

children.name: group
children.desc: The decision maker is a group of participants. Each decision maker group makes a single decision, to be then matched with other decisions in the game and produce an outcome for all decision makers involved (e.g., two groups of three participants make two decisions to be matched in a  PDG)

children.name: High
children.desc: Large relative size of the group

children.name: Low
children.desc: Small relative size of the group

children.name: Medium
children.desc: Medium relative size of the group

children.name: Size of unit of decision maker
children.desc: Number of participants constituting a single decision maker unit (e.g., if a 6-person public good is divided into 2 triads that each make decisions, then the decision maker unit size is 3; in a 6-person public good where each person makes their own decision, then the individual decision maker unit is 1).

children.name: Group size
children.desc: Overall number of people affected by the choices in the game.

children.name: Group size (correlation)
children.desc: Correlation between Group Size and behavior in the game.

children.name: Group size multilevel ratio
children.desc: Games can be multilevel in which contribution decisions do not involve a single group, but two or more groups of different sizes and participants can make decisions to contribute to local and global accounts (e.g., Buchan et al., 2011). It is calculated as number of participants in the smallest unit divided by number of total participants in the broader collective.

children.name: Number of decision makers
children.desc: Number of decision makers that each produce unique decisions that are used to calculate the collective payoff (e.g., 4 decision makers in a standard 4-persons PGD; 2 decision makers in a PDG with a 4-person group involving two subgroups that produce one decision each).

children.name: Choice
children.desc: Feedback about contributions, withdrawals, or binary decisions

children.name: Earnings
children.desc: Feedback about earnings (included ranks based on earnings and performance)

children.name: Failure
children.desc: Feedback about the failure of the group in reaching some payoff-relevant threshold in the game

children.name: Success
children.desc: Feedback about the success of the group in reaching some payoff-relevant threshold in the game

children.name: Others
children.desc: Feedback about other payoff-relevant information not mentioned in any of the Feedback content categories

children.name: Rank
children.desc: Feedback about the rank of participants in terms of their behavior (e.g., from the most cooperative to the least cooperative)

children.name: Individual
children.desc: Feedback about each group memberâs behavior is provided

children.name: Group
children.desc: Feedback about the groupâs aggregate behavior (e.g., mean contribution, sum of contributions)

children.name: Absent
children.desc: No feedback is provided

children.name: Other
children.desc: Feedback about behavior of other specific participants in the game that do not fall under any of the Feedback target categories (e.g., only feedback from a few individuals is provided)

children.name: Network
children.desc: Feedback about the aggregate behavior of all individuals belonging to the same network, if networks are present in the game

children.name: Leader
children.desc: Exclusively feedback about the leader's behavior, if a leader is present in the game

children.name: Noise
children.desc: Whether there is a mismatch (either positive or negative) between participants intended behavior and actual behavior communicated to one's partner. TRUE = Presence of a mismatch (either positive or negative) between participants intended behavior and actual behavior communicated to one's partner, FALSE = Absence of a mismatch (either positive or negative) between participants intended behavior and actual behavior communicated to one's partner.

children.name: Preprogrammed Cooperation Rate
children.desc: The partner cooperates randomly with a given cooperation rate across the duration of the game

children.name: Tit-for-Tat
children.desc: The partner cooperates on the first trial, then copies the previous choices of the focal participant on each subsequent trial

children.name: Other
children.desc: Other strategies

children.name: Predominantly Cooperative
children.desc: Partner cooperates over most trials, but the study doesn't specify the exact rate

children.name: Predominantly Competitive
children.desc: Partner competes over most trials, but the study doesn't specify the exact rate

children.name: Real Partner
children.desc: No experimental strategy is used and participants are playing according to actual game choices

children.name: Extortionate Zero Determinant
children.desc: Extortionate strategies have three properties: (1) they enforce a linear relationship between the playerâs own payoff and the opponentâs payoff; (2) they prescribe to cooperate sufficiently often, such that the opponentâs best response is to be fully cooperative; (3) at the same time, extortioners aim to cooperate less often than their opponent, to gain higher payoffs

children.name: Generous Zero Determinant
children.desc: Generous ZD strategies share the first two properties of extortioners: they enforce a linear relationship between the payoffs of the two players, and they provide incentives for the opponent to cooperate. However, as opposed to extortioners who aim to outcompete their opponents, the payoff of generous players never exceeds the payoff of the co-player

children.name: Pavlov
children.desc: The partner cooperates with probability 0.5 in the first move, then cooperates if and only if both players opted for the same choice in the previous trial

children.name: Tit-for-Tat+1
children.desc: The partner cooperates on the first trial, and then copies the choices of the focal participant with a delay (i.e., cooperates when the focal agent cooperates, but defects only after two consecutive defections from the focal participant)

children.name: GRIT
children.desc: GRIT strategy involves a statement of intent prior to interaction, specific announcements of choices prior to making their choice, and some retaliation in response to being exploited.

children.name: Unspecified
children.desc: The paper reports that the partner(s) was following a strategy, but does not specify which one

children.name: GRIM
children.desc: Initially, a partner using grim trigger will cooperate, but as soon as the participant defects (thus satisfying the trigger condition), a partner using grim trigger will defect for the remainder of the iterated game.

children.name: Prior Contribution
children.desc: Target agent made a contribution (value to be specified in one-shot strategy value) or cooperated

children.name: Prior Withdrawal
children.desc: Target agent made a withdrawal (value to be specified in one-shot strategy value) or defected

children.name: Iterated pre-programmed cooperation rate
children.desc: The pre-programmed cooperation rate of a partner (0.5 is 'random').

children.name: Iterated pre-programmed cooperation rate level
children.desc: Relative level of the pre-programmed cooperation rate of a partner.

children.name: One-shot strategy value
children.desc: The contribution or withdrawal of the participant's partner when one-shot strategy is Prior Contribution or Prior Withdrawal (1 indicates full cooperation from the partner, while 0 indicates full defection).
The reward treatment

The baseline treatment. This is the treatment compared against any treatment coded as reward treatment (= 1 identifies the reward effect). This means that the treatment is equal to the reward treatment, except for the availability of reward (which includes other concepts that are part of reward, such as reward effectiveness, etc.)
Is not a reward treatment. This is any treatment that is neither a punishment treatment nor a baseline relative to the punishment treatment (In practice, these are ignored in the platform)

children.name: Simultaneous
children.desc: Participants make the reward decision at the same time (i.e., without receiving information about others' reward decisions)

children.name: Sequential leadership-by-example
children.desc: In a game with leadership by example, there is a single privileged participant that makes a reward decision before all others

children.name: Sequential turn-taking
children.desc: Each participant makes a reward decision in turn

children.name: Monetary
children.desc: An amount of money often converted from game points

children.name: Non-monetary Social
children.desc: Participants receive social incentives, such as blame or praise, from others based on the outcomes of the game

children.name: Hypothetical
children.desc: Hypothetical value for participants (e.g., points)

children.name: Non-monetary Material
children.desc: Amount of other resources (e.g., candies, school supplies)

children.name: Peer
children.desc: Other participants of the same role

children.name: Institution
children.desc: Institutional mechanism inside (e.g., impersonal sanctioning system) or outside (e.g., public institutions like government)

children.name: Other
children.desc: Other agent types not included in the current categories

children.name: Leader
children.desc: A participant with some form of higher, relative social power; see Power

children.name: Third Party
children.desc: A person who does not interact with the participants in the main game e.g., a third-party punisher

children.name: Experimenter
children.desc: The person in charge of running the experiment (e.g., principle investigator, research assistant)

children.name: Computer
children.desc: Computerized opponent, and players were informed to be interacting with a computer

children.name: Network
children.desc: A peer in a game with network structure

children.name: Contribution-based
children.desc: Participants who made a contribution less (or more) than a specified amount are rewarded

children.name: Rank-based
children.desc: The n lowest- (or highest-) ranked participants are rewarded

children.name: Random
children.desc: Random players are rewarded

children.name: Outcome-based
children.desc: Some set of players are rewarded if a collective threshold is (not) reached

children.name: Focal participant has rewarded
children.desc: Whether the focal participant rewarded another player in the previous trial of the game. TRUE = Focal participant rewarded another player in the previous trial, FALSE = Focal participant did not reward another player in the previous trial.

children.name: Lottery reward incentive
children.desc: Whether there was a chance of lottery for a reward to occur (see lottery incentive). TRUE = A lottery was implemented for reward to occur, FALSE = A lottery was not implemented for reward to occur.

children.name: Reward effectiveness
children.desc: The ratio of the cost of reward for the participant who decides to reward, to the benefit of reward for the participant who receives the reward (e.g., if the reward costs 1 point to deliver and benefits the recipient by 3 points, = .33).

children.name: Reward iterations
children.desc: The number of iterations of reward per reward phase.

children.name: Reward probability
children.desc: The probability that a reward decision is played out (and thus becomes beneficial to the rewarded agent).

children.name: Endowment
children.desc: Number of tokens participants were endowed with in a Public Goods Game

children.name: Payoff matrix
children.desc: The matrix that represents the possible behaviors and outcomes for the participants

children.name: MPCR
children.desc: The ratio of benefits to costs for a member to contribute one monetary unit to the group account (calculated as multiplier divided by group size)

children.name: Incentives
children.desc: How participantsâ decisions in the game determine their payoffs in different forms

children.name: Return from public account
children.desc: Payoff obtained from the tokens invested in the public account

children.name: Other
children.desc: Other aspects of the game that was manipulated with respect to symmetry

children.name: Punishment effectiveness
children.desc: The ratio of the cost of punishment to the punishing agent to the cost of punishment to the punished agent

children.name: Lottery prize
children.desc: Bonuses that were allocated through a lottery-like mechanism (this bonus is additional to return from private and public goods accounts)

children.name: Payment chance
children.desc: Chance to receive payment based on the outcome of the game

children.name: Private account return
children.desc: Private gain for each token contributed to the private account

children.name: Marginal rate of substitution
children.desc: Tradeoff between contribution and return from the public good, in order to keep the subjective utility constant

children.name: Symmetry
children.desc: Whether specific aspects of the game that were different (i.e., asymmetric) for participants. TRUE = Symmetric, FALSE = Asymmetric.

children.name: Endogenous
children.desc: With endogenous institutions, participants can influence the type of institution provided

children.name: Exogenous
children.desc: With exogenous institutions, the structure of the game is given and cannot be changed by players

children.name: Vote
children.desc: Participants can establish different institutions by vote, requiring some threshold (simple majority, consensus, etc.)

children.name: Choice
children.desc: Individual participants can choose to impose an institution on themselves or others.

children.name: Migration
children.desc: Participants can choose between groups with different institutions

children.name: Establish
children.desc: Vote to establish a new institution

children.name: Other
children.desc: Other votes (e.g., alter an existing institution)

children.name: Remove
children.desc: Vote to remove an existing institution

children.name: Taxation
children.desc: Mandatory minimum contributions or taxation set that participants must make. Taxation is institutional (i.e., the threshold is set by an institution)

children.name: Punishment
children.desc: Punishment is the imposition of negative payoffs on a specific participant after a trial in the game

children.name: Other
children.desc: Any other institution

children.name: Reward
children.desc: Reward is the imposition of positive payoffs on a specific participant after a trial in the game

children.name: Leadership
children.desc: There is a person in the dilemma known as the leader who has a specific role and can influence followers

children.name: Ostracism
children.desc: Participants can be avoided or rejected from a group

children.name: Yes Vote
children.desc: The proposal reached the threshold (the institution was established, removed, altered, etc.)

children.name: No Vote
children.desc: The proposal did not reach the threshold (the institution was not established, removed, altered, etc.)

children.name: Sequential turn-taking
children.desc: Participants make decisions one after another following some (endogenous or exogenous) order

children.name: Simultaneous
children.desc: Participants make decisions simultaneously

children.name: Sequential leadership-by-example
children.desc: One (endogenously or exogenously determined) participant makes a first decision, then all other participants make their decisions simultaneously. This does not include two-player sequential games, which should be coded as sequential turn-taking

children.name: Endogenous position
children.desc: Whether the position in the sequence is exogenous (i.e., predetermined) or endogenous (i.e., based on players' decisions). Endogenous could also be choosing that the game is sequential and/or choosing position in the game. TRUE = Endogenous, FALSE = Exogenous.

children.name: Position in game
children.desc: The positional order of the participant in the sequence of decisions (in a sequential game).

children.name: Exogenous
children.desc: Leader is assigned by the experimenter or some external mechanism

children.name: Endogenous
children.desc: Leader is selected by participants in the game

children.name: Random Appointment
children.desc: Leader is randomly appointed

children.name: Elected
children.desc: Leader is voted and elected by other participants

children.name: Volunteer
children.desc: Participants volunteer to be the leader

children.name: Fixed
children.desc: Leader is fixed throughout the game

children.name: Authority
children.desc: Leader is selected by an authority figure (or by being an authority figure)

children.name: Other
children.desc: Other unclassified rules to select leaders

children.name: Rotating
children.desc: Leader position rotates within the group

children.name: Follower
children.desc: Follower behavior in the game

children.name: Leader
children.desc: Leader behavior in the game

children.name: Cooperative
children.desc: Leader behaved cooperatively in the game

children.name: Noncooperative
children.desc: Leader behaved noncooperatively in the game

children.name: Absent
children.desc: Information was not provided to participants about how the leader behaved in the game

children.name: Strong
children.desc: Leader was strong (e.g., a stronger influence on followers)

children.name: Male
children.desc: Leader was male

children.name: Female
children.desc: Leader was female

children.name: Positive emotion
children.desc: Leader expressed positivity

children.name: Weak
children.desc: Leader was weak (e.g., a weaker influence on followers)

children.name: Negative emotion
children.desc: Leader expressed negativity

children.name: Outgroup
children.desc: Leader was an outgroup member

children.name: Ingroup
children.desc: Leader was an ingroup member

children.name: Leadership
children.desc: There is a person in the game that is recognized as the leader who has specific roles that can influence followers. TRUE = A leader is present in the game, FALSE = A leader is absent in the game.

children.name: Cooperative
children.desc: Cooperative frames refer to the participants common interests

children.name: Competitive
children.desc: Competitive frames refer to discord and rivalry among the participants

children.name: Generic
children.desc: Generic frames refer to concepts of moral, competitive, or cooperative

children.name: Moral
children.desc: Moral frames refer to how one ought to behave, for example, in terms of fairness, religious appeals, and responsibility for each otherâs payoffs

children.name: Give-some
children.desc: The game is framed as a give-some dilemma, i.e., endowments are allocated to the player and can be contributed to the public good.

children.name: Take-some
children.desc: The game is framed as a take-some dilemma, i.e., endowment is allocated to the public good (or common resource) and can be extracted by the player.

children.name: Gain
children.desc: The game is framed in terms of gains, i.e., outcomes of decisions are positively-valued.

children.name: Loss
children.desc: The game is framed in terms of losses, i.e., outcomes of decisions are negatively-valued. This includes games in which only some outcomes are negatively valued.

children.name: Public Good
children.desc: The game is framed in terms of positive outcomes to others arising from contributions to the public good.

children.name: Public Bad
children.desc: The game is framed in terms of negative outcomes to others arising from contributions to the public bad or in terms of negative externalities from contributions to the private good.

children.name: Focal point frame
children.desc: In coordination games, frames can used techniques to refer participants to a unique but principally arbitrary move by highlighting one particular choice (e.g., by bolding the text in one cell). TRUE = Has a focal point frame, FALSE = Has no focal point frame.

children.name: Structural
children.desc: Structural manipulations of power involve varying control over one's own or others' resources (e.g., having more points to invest in a game or having stronger punishment ratios) (Nieper et al., 2018)

children.name: Experiential
children.desc: Experiential manipulations of power activate the experience of power via an episodic recall or an imagined role manipulation (e.g., recalling a time when one felt powerful, or imagining alternatives) (Nieper et al., 2018)

children.name: Conceptual
children.desc: Conceptual manipulations of power involve semantically or visually priming the concept of power (e.g. through word puzzles or scrambled-sentence tasks) (Nieper et al., 2018)

children.name: Physical
children.desc: Physical manipulations of power involve an individualâs physical posture or nonverbal behavior (e.g. power posing) (Nieper et al., 2018)

children.name: High
children.desc: The participant has more control over resources relative to another person

children.name: Low
children.desc: The participant has less control over resources relative to another person.

children.name: Control
children.desc: The participant has equal control over resources relative to another person.

children.name: Endowment
children.desc: One party has more resources available relative to another party in an interdependent situation. The one with more resources has more control over the outcome of the other and is thus more powerful (Nieper et al., 2018)

children.name: Benefit
children.desc: One party gains a greater benefit from the outcomes of the game (e.g., higher return from the public goods, higher MPCR, higher rewards in the PDG)

children.name: Recall
children.desc: Participants recall a time when they were powerful (Nieper et al., 2018)

children.name: Punishment
children.desc: In interdependent situations, if one party can punish or has a better punishment ratio in comparison to others with no/less punishment power, the person with the better ratio, is more powerful (Nieper et al., 2018)

children.name: Role Assignment
children.desc: A participant is assigned a role for the task that is either associated with high power (e.g. leader, boss) or low power (e.g. follower, subordinate) (Nieper et al., 2018)

children.name: Alternative
children.desc: When interacting with others, the person with a better alternative is less dependent on the other person that they are interacting with and thus more powerful (Nieper et al., 2018)

children.name: first
children.desc: Cooperation assessed in the first trial

children.name: last
children.desc: Cooperation assessed in the last trial

children.name: other
children.desc: Cooperation assessed in a different trial than the first or last

children.name: first
children.desc: Cooperation assessed in the first block

children.name: last
children.desc: Cooperation assessed in the last block

children.name: other
children.desc: Cooperation assessed in a different block than the first or last

children.name: Block of cooperation
children.desc: Block on which cooperation is assessed. Blocks are defined as chunks of trials aggregated together. Trials can be grouped in a block based on some manipulation in the game, but can also be aggregated based on arbitrary reasons not related to the study design (e.g., statistical analyses).

children.name: Trial of cooperation
children.desc: Trial on which cooperation is assessed.

children.name: Low
children.desc: The treatment was classified as having a relative low level of anonymity

children.name: High
children.desc: The treatment was classified as having a relative high level of anonymity

children.name: Medium
children.desc: The treatment was classified as having a relative medium level of anonymity

children.name: absent
children.desc: Participants were not provided information about how their partner behaved in the current game or had behaved with others in a previous game

children.name: present
children.desc: Participants were provided information about how their partner behaved in the current game or had behaved with others in a previous game

children.name: noncooperative
children.desc: Participants were provided with the information that their partner behaved noncooperatively

children.name: cooperative
children.desc: Participants were provided with the information that their partner behaved cooperatively

children.name: present
children.desc: Participants can be chosen for interactions based on past behavior

children.name: absent
children.desc: Participants can not be chosen for interactions based on past behavior

children.name: Present
children.desc: Gossip was present in the study

children.name: Absent
children.desc: Gossip was absent in the study

children.name: Anonymity
children.desc: Correlation between cooperation and individual differences in the extent that participants felt anonymous when making their decisions (higher scores equal more anonymity, lower identifiability).

children.name: Low
children.desc: The treatment was classified as having a relative low level of uncertainty

children.name: High
children.desc: The treatment was classified as having a relative high level of uncertainty

children.name: Medium
children.desc: The treatment was classified as having a relative medium level of uncertainty

children.name: Return from public account
children.desc: Payoff obtained from the tokens invested in the public account

children.name: Incentive structure
children.desc: Information about how payoffs in the game are determined. Stochastic vs deterministic payoff structures are included in this category

children.name: MPCR
children.desc: The ratio of benefits to costs for a member to contribute one monetary unit to the group account

children.name: Threshold
children.desc: The minimum threshold of total contribution by all group members for the public good to be provided or the occurrence of a loss (e.g., in case of public bad games)

children.name: Endowment size
children.desc: Information about maximum number of tokens participants were endowed with (or could contribute/harvest)

children.name: Provision probability
children.desc: Probability to obtain a group payoff as a result of the public goods allocation

children.name: Return from private account
children.desc: Payoff obtained from the tokens invested in the private account

children.name: Loss
children.desc: Negative payoff that resulted in a loss of resources due to endogenous (e.g., not reaching a threshold) or exogenous  (e.g., shocks) factors

children.name: Replenishment rate
children.desc: The replenishment rate in the resource dilemma. The remaining resource in the common pool is multiplied by the replenishment rate (â¥1) after each trial

children.name: Feedback
children.desc: information participants receive after each decision round

children.name: Group size
children.desc: Overall number of people affected by the outcome of the game

children.name: Exogenous
children.desc: Players are matched based on some (non-random) characteristic (e.g., personality, prior play)

children.name: Endogenous
children.desc: Players choose with whom to interact

children.name: Migration
children.desc: Players can choose to enter different groups (but not specific players, as all players can migrate)

children.name: Partner
children.desc: Participants interact with the same partner for multiple trials

children.name: Stranger
children.desc: Participants interact with one person for one trial (i.e., one-shot), or switch partners after each trial across many trials (i.e., one-shot repeated)

children.name: Partner's choice
children.desc: Partner choice involves matching of participants based on either the players' or the experimenter's decision. If partner choice is in place, code for partner choice

children.name: Individual group
children.desc: Group of individuals making decisions that only affect that group

children.name: intergroup competition
children.desc: Two groups and the higher earning group wins, or earns more

children.name: intergroup comparison
children.desc: Two groups and the outcomes of the two groups are compared, but no tangible consequence results from the comparison

children.name: Intergroup Prisoner's Dilemma
children.desc: âThe individualsâ payoff for defecting or withholding contribution is higher than his or her payoff for contribution, regardless of what all others (ingroup and outgroup) players do. Withholding contribution, in other words, is the dominant individual strategy. The payoff for i when all in-group members contribute is higher than iâs payoff when none contributes, regardless of the number of out-group contributors. Thus, the dominant group strategy is for all group members to contribute. Player iâs payoff when all players in both groups contribute is lower than his or her payoff when none contributes. This means that the collectively (i.e., Pareto) optimal outcome, the one that maximizes the collective payoff to all players in both groups, is for all of them to withhold contributionâ (Goren & Bornstein, 2000, p. 701).

children.name: intergroup harmony
children.desc: Two groups and decisions to cooperate within either group benefit both groups

children.name: intergroup conflict
children.desc: two groups and cooperating with own group, harms other group

children.name: Prosocial/Trustworthy
children.desc: Partner is perceived to be prosocial/trustworthy

children.name: Competent
children.desc: Partner is perceived to be competent

children.name: Moral
children.desc: Partner is perceived to be moral

children.name: Attractive
children.desc: Partner is perceived to be physically attractive

children.name: Liking
children.desc: Participants report to like the partner

children.name: Proself/Untrustworthy
children.desc: Partner is perceived to be proself/untrustworthy

children.name: Status
children.desc: Participans are perceived to have a relative social or professional standing

children.name: Positive
children.desc: Partner is generally perceived with a positive connotation (coded when the other categories did not apply)

children.name: Close
children.desc: Partner is perceived to be close

children.name: Familiar
children.desc: Partner is perceived to be familiar

children.name: Dominant
children.desc: Partner is perceived to be dominant

children.name: Unattractive
children.desc: Partner is perceived to be physically unattractive

children.name: Negative
children.desc: Partner is generally perceived with a negative connotation  (coded when the other categories did not apply)

children.name: Warm
children.desc: Partner is perceived to be warm

children.name: Control
children.desc: Partner is perceived to be controlling

children.name: high
children.desc: The partner is perceived as high in reference to a specific quality (this may be manipulated or measured in the study)

children.name: low
children.desc: The partner is perceived as low in reference to a specific quality (this may be manipulated or measured in the study)

children.name: control
children.desc: A control condition whereby no information is provided in reference to a specific quality

children.name: F
children.desc: Female

children.name: M
children.desc: Male

children.name: Low
children.desc: The similarity between the participant and their partner(s) is low

children.name: High
children.desc: The similarity between the participant and their partner(s) is high

children.name: Medium
children.desc: The similarity between the participant and their partner(s) is medium

children.name: Mandatory Minimum
children.desc: Minimum contribution is automatically contributed to the public good

children.name: Suggested Minimum
children.desc: A minimum contribution is suggested, but not automatically transferred. May be enforced (e.g., through punishment)

children.name: None
children.desc: No minimum contribution

children.name: Income tax
children.desc: Taxation on income takes a proportion of players' income (from public and private good, net of contributions) and redistributes it among players. Redistribution may be unequal. TRUE = Income tax exists, FALSE = No income tax exists.

children.name: Income tax rate
children.desc: The proportion of net income taken under the tax.

children.name: Income tax rate level
children.desc: The relative level of the proportion of net income taken under the tax.

children.name: Minimum contribution level
children.desc: The relative level of the minimum contribution to the public good as a proportion of the endowment.

children.name: Minimum contribution value
children.desc: The value of the minimum contribution to the public good as a proportion of the endowment.

children.name: Monetary
children.desc: Decisions in the game resulted in monetary outcomes, often converted from game points

children.name: Hypothetical
children.desc: Decisions in the game resulted in outcomes with hypothetical value for participants (e.g., points)

children.name: Non-monetary Material
children.desc: Decisions in the game resulted in outcomes involving some amount of other (non-monetary) material resource (e.g., candies, school supplies)

children.name: Non-monetary Social
children.desc: Decisions in the game resulted players receiving social incentives, such as blame or praise, from others based on the outcome of the game

children.name: Lottery incentive
children.desc: Whether the study involved a lottery to get paid (monetary or non-monetary) resources based on the outcome of the game. TRUE = A lottery was implemented as incentive, FALSE = A lottery was not implemented as incentive.

children.name: Show-up fee
children.desc: Whether participants received a show-up fee for the study (i.e., a certain payment for participation). TRUE = Show-up fee, FALSE = No show-up fee.

children.name: Repeated
children.desc: Participants played the game repeatedly with the same person

children.name: One-shot
children.desc: Participants played the game with the same person only once

children.name: Continuation probability
children.desc: In some games, there is no pre-specified number of trials; rather there is a prespecified probability that the block or session ends at each trial. This probability may only kick in after a prespecified number of trials (e.g., minimum of 10 trials, then the game ends with p = 0.5).

children.name: Continuation probability level
children.desc: Relative gain of the prespecified probability that the block or session ends at each trial.

children.name: Known endgame
children.desc: Whether participants know the exact number of trials at the beginning of the experiment. Endgame is considered known also when participants played a one-shot game. TRUE = Known endgame, FALSE = Endgame not known.

children.name: Number of blocks
children.desc: The total number of blocks across the full experimental session. A block is a unit within the experiment in which trials have the same treatment and matching procedure. E.g., ten trials of partner-matched play followed by ten trials of partner-matched play with a different partner are two blocks of ten trials (because re-matching takes place). Ten trials of stranger-matched play followed by ten more trials of stranger-matched play are one block of 20 trials. Ten trials of stranger-matched play as baseline followed by ten more trials of stranger-matched play with punishment are two blocks of ten trials, as the treatment changes. Thus, divisions of trials into blocks only for analysis are not treated as blocks.

children.name: Number of blocks level
children.desc: Relative level of the total number of blocks across the full experimental session.

children.name: Number of sessions
children.desc: The number of full experimental sessions. Each session involves multiple blocks (i.e., iterated games of varying, but predetermined length).

children.name: Number of trials
children.desc: The number of trials (rounds) in each block.

children.name: Number of trials level
children.desc: Relative level of the number of trials (rounds) in each block.

children.name: time pressure
children.desc: Participants are given a limited amount of time and asked to make their decision as quickly as possible

children.name: time delay
children.desc: Participants are given relatively more time to think carefully about their decision before making it

children.name: Control
children.desc: Participants do not receive any instructions regarding the time they have to spend to make a decision

children.name: Fast
children.desc: Participants were categorized as fast in providing their decisions

children.name: Slow
children.desc: Participants were categorized as slow in providing their decisions

children.name: Decision time (correlation)
children.desc: Correlation between cooperation and time participants spend to make the decision.

children.name: Neutral
children.desc: Often used as a baseline in studies that elicit emotions. Participants are exposed either to stimuli with neutral emotional valence or engage in a non-emotional control task

children.name: Anger
children.desc: The response to interference with pursuit of a goal the participant cares about (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Empathy
children.desc: âOtherâcenteredâ emotion, which can result from observing another individual in need and imagining the person's situation (Batson, 1991)

children.name: Sadness
children.desc: The response to the loss of an object or person to which a person is very attached (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Guilt
children.desc: The response when a person regrets having violated an agreement, principle, or value (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Disgust
children.desc: The repulsion by the sight, smell, or taste of something; disgust may also be provoked by people whose actions are revolting or by ideas that are offensive (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Happiness
children.desc: Feelings that are enjoyed, that are sought by the person (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Fear
children.desc: The response to the threat of harm (physical or psychological; Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Other emotion
children.desc: None of the emotion categories apply

children.name: Self-consciousness
children.desc: Emotion(s) that involve self-reflection and self-evaluation (e.g., guilt, shame, pride, embarrassment; Tagney, 1999)

children.name: Gratitude
children.desc: Pleasant feelings toward a target about the benefits received

children.name: Shame
children.desc: The response when a person feels that if their true nature was to be known, others would be repulsed (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Disappointment
children.desc: A response to unfulfilled positive expectations (Van Dijk et al., 1999)

children.name: Regret
children.desc: Emotion elicited by a comparison between the outcome of a choice (reality) and the better outcome of foregone rejected alternatives (what might have been) (Coricelli et al. 2007)

children.name: Surprise
children.desc: The response to a sudden unexpected event (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Contempt
children.desc: Feeling morally superior to another person (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Envy
children.desc: The response to another personâs rewards which the envious person wishes to have (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011).

children.name: Embarrassment
children.desc: The response when people feel they have broken a social rule, and also when a person has been praised (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: positive
children.desc: The participant experiences an emotion considered as pleasant and attractive

children.name: negative
children.desc: The participant experiences an emotion considered as unpleasant and unattractive

children.name: neutral
children.desc: The participant experiences an emotional state that can not be classified as positive or negative

children.name: Other
children.desc: None of the emotion display categories apply

children.name: Facial
children.desc: Participants learn about partner's emotions via facial expressions

children.name: Posture
children.desc: Participants learn about the partner's emotions via body position

children.name: Vocal
children.desc: Participants learn about the partner's emotions via vocal cues (e.g., tone of voice)

children.name: Neutral
children.desc: Often used as a baseline in studies that elicit emotions. Participants are exposed either to stimuli with neutral emotional valence or engage in a non-emotional control task

children.name: Anger
children.desc: The response to interference with our pursuit of a goal an agent cares about (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Happiness
children.desc: Feelings that are enjoyed, that are sought by the person (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Disappointment
children.desc: Emotion experienced in response to unfulfilled positive expectations (Van Dijk et al., 1999)

children.name: Guilt
children.desc: The response when a person regrets having violated an agreement, principle, or value (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Embarrassment
children.desc: The response when people feel they have broken a social rule, and also when a person has been praised (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Disgust
children.desc: The repulsion by the sight, smell, or taste of something; disgust may also be provoked by people whose actions are revolting or by ideas that are offensive (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Shame
children.desc: The response when a person feels that if their true nature was to be known, others would be repulsed (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Fear
children.desc: The response to the threat of harm, physical or psychological (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Empathy
children.desc: âOtherâcenteredâ emotion, which can result from observing another individual in need and imagining the person's situation (Batson, 1991)

children.name: Envy
children.desc: The response to another personâs rewards which the envious person wishes to have (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Self-consciousness
children.desc: Emotion(s) that involve self-reflection and self-evaluation (e.g., guilt, shame, pride, embarrassment; Tagney, 1999)

children.name: Contempt
children.desc: Feeling morally superior to another person (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Gratitude
children.desc: Pleasant feelings toward a target about the benefits received

children.name: Other emotion
children.desc: None of the emotion categories apply

children.name: Surprise
children.desc: The response to a sudden unexpected event (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Regret
children.desc: Emotion elicited by a comparison between the outcome of a choice (reality) and the better outcome of foregone rejected alternatives (what might have been) (Coricelli et al. 2007)

children.name: Sadness
children.desc: The response to the loss of an object or person to which you are very attached (Ekman & Cordaro, 2011)

children.name: Low
children.desc: Low strength of the experience emotion

children.name: High
children.desc: High strength of the experience emotion

children.name: Medium
children.desc: Middle strength of the experience emotion

children.name: negative
children.desc: The partner experiences or displays an emotional state that can not be classified as positive or negative

children.name: positive
children.desc: The partner experiences or displays an emotion considered as pleasant and attractive

children.name: neutral
children.desc: The partner experiences or displays an emotion considered as unpleasant and unattractive

children.name: Emotion manipulation
children.desc: Whether emotions of participants were elicited experimentally or measured through some instruments (e.g., questionnaires). TRUE = Participant's emotions were experimentally manipulated, FALSE = Participant's emotions were measured.

children.name: Partner's emotion manipulation
children.desc: Whether emotions of the partner were elicited experimentally or measured through some instruments (e.g., questionnaires). TRUE = Partner's emotions were experimentally manipulated, FALSE = Partner's emotions were measures.

children.name: Computer
children.desc: Computerized opponent. Players must be informed to be interacting with a computer

children.name: Stranger
children.desc: General others outside the game (in formulations such as 'most people'; 'others in general'...)

children.name: Peer
children.desc: Other player(s) of the same role as the participant (unless the participant is a Leader)

children.name: Other
children.desc: Partner types not included in the other categories

children.name: Unspecified
children.desc: The type is not specified

children.name: Experimenter
children.desc: The person in charge of running the experiment (such as the principle investigator, research assistant)

children.name: Leader
children.desc: A person with some form of power over the other players

children.name: Institution
children.desc: Institutional mechanism inside (e.g., impersonal sanctioning system) or outside (e.g., public institutions like government)

children.name: Network
children.desc: A peer in a game with network structure

children.name: Third Party
children.desc: A person who does not interact with the participant in the main game, e.g. a third-party punisher

children.name: Other Game
children.desc: None of the game type categories apply

children.name: Prisoner's Dilemma Game
children.desc: In the standard prisoner's dilemma game, the relative value of the four outcomes reflects the following relationships: DC > CC > DD > CD

children.name: Continuous Public Goods Game
children.desc: In the continuous public goods game, subjects are provided an endowment and decide any portion to allocate to the public good, and the remaining about is kept for themselves. The group contributions in the public pool are multiplied by a factor (greater than one and less than the number of players, N) and it is divided among players, regardless of the players contributions

children.name: Chicken Game
children.desc: In the standard chicken game, the relative value of the four outcomes reflects the following relationships: DC > CC > CD > DD

children.name: Step-level Public Goods Game
children.desc: In the step level public goods game, subjects are provided an endowment and decide any portion of the endowment to allocate to the public good, and the remaining amonut is kept for themselves. The group contributions to the public pool are multiplied by a factor and it is divided among players (regardless of their contributions) only if a certain threshold (provision point) is met

children.name: Stag Hunt
children.desc: In the standard stag hunt, the relative value of the four outcomes reflects the following relationships: CC >  DC â¥ DD > CD

children.name: Resource Dilemma
children.desc: In the standard resource dilemma game, players harvest resources from a common resource pool of known size, and after each trial the pool is replenished at a predetermined rate and is exhausted when the withdrawals exceed the resource in the pool

children.name: Intergroup Prisoner's Dilemma
children.desc: In the intergroup prisoner's dilemma game, different groups of players play together with a PDG structure. However, payoff to a player is an increasing (or at least nondecreasing) function of the total contribution made by members of his or her own group and a decreasing (or at least nonincreasing) function of the total contribution made by members of the opposing group

children.name: Dictator Game
children.desc: In standard dictator game, participants are assigned to either the role of dictator or recipient. The dictator is given a fixed amount of money and is entitled to decide how much money to keep and how much money to give to the recipient

children.name: Trust Game - receiver
children.desc: In the standard trust game, players are provided an endowment, paired, and assigned to either the role of sender or receiver. At stage one of the game, the sender may either pass nothing, or any portion of the endowment to the receiver. The sender then keeps the remaining endowment for themselves. The experimenter then triples the amount sent to the receiver. In stage two, the receiver may either pass nothing, or pass any portion of the money received back to the sender.

children.name: Trust Game - sender
children.desc: In the standard trust game, players are provided an endowment, paired, and assigned to either the role of sender or receiver. At stage one of the game, the sender may either pass nothing, or any portion of the endowment to the receiver. The sender then keeps the remaining endowment for themselves. The experimenter then triples the amount sent to the receiver. In stage two, the receiver may either pass nothing, or pass any portion of the money received back to the sender

children.name: Ultimatum game - Responder
children.desc: In standard ultimatum game, the first player proposes how to divide a sum of money with the second party. If the second player rejects this division, neither gets anything. If the second player accepts, the first gets her demand and the second gets the rest

children.name: Intergroup Prisoner's Dilemma-Maximizing Differences
children.desc: The game is played by two groups. Each player receives an endowment and can contribute any portion to the groupâs fund. For each token contributed by a member of the in-group, each of its members, including the contributor, gains a specific amount and each member of the out-group loses a specified amount. The tokens kept for oneself are doubled.

children.name: Ultimatum game - Proposer
children.desc: In standard ultimatum game, the first player proposes how to divide a sum of money with the second party. If the second player rejects this division, neither gets anything. If the second player accepts, the first gets her demand and the second gets the rest

children.name: Intergroup Public Goods Game
children.desc: In the intergroup public goods game, different groups of players play together with a PGD structure. However, payoff to a player is an increasing (or at least nondecreasing) function of the total contribution made by members of his or her own group and a decreasing (or at least nonincreasing) function of the total contribution made by members of the opposing group.

children.desc: In standard ultimatum game, the first player proposes how to divide a sum of money with the second party. If the second player rejects this division, neither gets anything. If the second player accepts, the first gets her demand and the second gets the rest

children.desc: In the standard prisoner's dilemma game, the relative value of the four outcomes reflects the following relationships: DC > CC > DD > CD
