children.name: Other game type
children.desc: If none of the game type categories apply, then we report the name of the game included in the study.

children.name: Other
children.desc: Other primes

children.name: Neutral
children.desc: No prime or a neutral prime

children.name: Cooperation
children.desc: A prime that may increase cooperation; includes primes about the concept of cooperation, community, interdependence, shared identity

children.name: Competition
children.desc: A prime that may increase non-cooperation; such as conflict, business or economic context

children.name: Religion
children.desc: A prime that relates to religion

children.name: Power
children.desc: A prime that relates to the concept of power

children.name: Morality
children.desc: A prime that relates to the concept of morality

children.name: White
children.desc: Europe, Middle East, North Africa

children.name: Black or African American
children.desc: Africa

children.name: Other
children.desc: nan

children.name: Asian
children.desc: Far East, Southeast Asia, Indian

children.name: American Indian or Alaska Native
children.desc: North America, South America, Central America

children.name: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander
children.desc: Hawaii, Guam, Samoa, Pacific Islands

children.name: Heterogeneous ethnicity
children.desc: Whether groups had a mixed ethnic composition (also applies to mixed nationalities and small-scale societies). TRUE = Groups had a mixed ethnic composition (also applies to mixed nationalities and small-scale societies), FALSE = Groups had a homogeneous ethnic composition (also applies to nationalities and small-scale societies).

children.name: Nationality or region
children.desc: Participant's nationality according to ISO-3 Country Code.

children.name: Small-scale society
children.desc: Participant's small-scale society of origin, according to the d-place classification. "Other" if small-scale society is not included in the d-society classification . A society can be understood to represent a group of people at a focal location with a shared language that differs from that of their neighbors" (Kirby et al., 2016).

children.name: stranger
children.desc: Their partner is a stranger

children.name: friend
children.desc: Their partner is a friend

children.name: acquaintance
children.desc: Their partner is an acquaintance

children.name: spouse
children.desc: Their partner is a spouse

children.name: sibling
children.desc: Their partner is a sibling

children.name: parent
children.desc: Their partner is a parent

children.name: son/daughter
children.desc: Their partner is a son/daughter

children.name: Degree of friendship
children.desc: Correlation between cooperation and the extent to which the participant and their partner(s) in the game describe themselves as friends.

children.name: High
children.desc: Participants have medium expectations about the other player(s)' behavior in the game

children.name: Low
children.desc: Participants have low expectations about the other player(s)' behavior in the game

children.name: Medium
children.desc: Participants have medium expectations about the other player(s)' behavior in the game

children.name: Expectations
children.desc: Correlation between cooperation and participants' expectations are stated beliefs about their partner's behavior, such as whether they will cooperate or defect, the probability that they will defect, or the expected size of their contribution to a public good.

children.name: Full Refund
children.desc: Participants are fully refunded any amount to contributed to the public good, often depending on contributions made by others

children.name: Absent
children.desc: No refund/rebate is provided

children.name: Partial Rebate
children.desc: Participants receive a partial refund (i.e., rebate) for their contribution to the public good, often depending on contributions made by others

children.name: Cooperative
children.desc: Cooperative goals aim to equalize and/or maximize joint outcomes

children.name: Competitive
children.desc: Competitive goals aim to maximize the relative difference between own and the othersâ outcome

children.name: Individualistic
children.desc: Individualistic goals aim to maximize own outcomes, regardless of the othersâ outcomes

children.name: Individualistic
children.desc: Individualistic goals aim to maximize own outcomes, regardless of the othersâ outcomes

children.name: Cooperative
children.desc: Cooperative goals aim to equalize and/or maximize joint outcomes

children.name: Competitive
children.desc: Competitive goals aim to maximize the relative difference between own and the othersâ outcome

children.name: Religious affiliation
children.desc: Participants reported to be affiliated to a specific religion

children.name: Religious attendance
children.desc: Participants reported the frequency of attending religious services (e.g., going to church)

children.name: Religious beliefs
children.desc: Participants reported beliefs toward the religious sphere (e.g., beliefs in God, extent to which they consider themselves as religious)

children.name: Religious setting
children.desc: Participants interacted in a religious setting (e.g., church)

children.name: High
children.desc: Participants were classified as having a relative high religious exposure

children.name: Low
children.desc: Participants were classified as having a relative low religious exposure

children.name: Medium
children.desc: Participants were classified as having a relative medium religious exposure

children.name: Religiosity
children.desc: Correlation between any individual difference construct pertaining to the religious sphere (e.g., beliefs in god, church attendance, religious affiliation) and cooperation.

children.name: Conditional cooperators
children.desc: Using the strategy method of contributions to public goods by Fischbacher et al. (2001), participants who had an increasing amount of contributions or had a significant positive slope of own contribution with average group contribution

children.name: Freeriders
children.desc: Using the strategy method of contributions to public goods by Fischbacher et al. (2001), participants who always contributed nothing to the public good

children.name: Others
children.desc: Using the strategy method of contributions to public goods by Fischbacher et al. (2001), participants unable to be classified as (un)conditional cooperators, free riders or hump shaped contributors

children.name: Hump-shaped contributors
children.desc: Using the strategy method of contributions to public goods by Fischbacher et al. (2001), participants who initially provide increasing amounts to the public good according to increasing average group contributions, but then at some point give a significantly decreasing amount to the public good

children.name: Unconditional cooperator
children.desc: Using the strategy method of contributions to public goods by Fischbacher et al. (2001), participants who always contributed the full amount to the public good

children.name: Lab
children.desc: The experiment was conducted in a laboratory (Classrooms used as laboratory setting are considered as lab)

children.name: Online
children.desc: The experiment was conducted online on a web platform (e.g., MTurk)

children.name: Field
children.desc: The experiment involved a manipulation carried out in the field (Subjects may or may not be aware that they are part of an experiment)

children.name: Lab in the field
children.desc: The experiment had all the characteristics of a lab experiment but it is carried out at a field site

children.name: Natural experiment
children.desc: A quasi-experiment in the field in which randomization is not controlled by the experimenter (e.g., a study using a TV game show)

children.name: Classroom
children.desc: The experiment was conducted during a regular class (e.g., during some demonstration of a negotiation task for teaching purposes)

children.name: old
children.desc: Participants were classified as middle old with respect to their age

children.name: young
children.desc: Participants were classified as young with respect to their age

children.name: middle
children.desc: Participants were classified as middle with respect to their age

children.name: Age
children.desc: Participants' age, usually measured as self-reported participants' person years.

children.name: Others
children.desc: Participants were students of other disciplines than economics, psychology, or sociology

children.name: Economics
children.desc: Participants were economics students

children.name: Psychology
children.desc: Participants were psychology students

children.name: Sociology
children.desc: Participants were sociology students

children.name: Senior
children.desc: Participants were classified as senior with respect to their academic grade

children.name: Junior
children.desc: Participants were classified as junior with respect to their academic grade

children.name: Middle
children.desc: Participants were classified as middle with respect to their academic grade

children.name: Academic grade
children.desc: Participants were grouped in different year groups (Values adopted from US educational system).

children.name: Academic performance
children.desc: Any indicator of how academic/school achievements (such as marks, grades, gpa, years of education). Achievement indicators can differ across countries and educational systems.

children.name: Knowledge of experimental games
children.desc: Whether participants report to have experience with economic games and/or game theory. TRUE = Participants report to have experience with economic games and/or game theory, FALSE = Participants report not to have experience with economic games and/or game theory.

children.name: Knowledge of experimental games (correlation)
children.desc: Correlation between reported experience with economic games and/or game theory and cooperation.

children.name: Student sample
children.desc: Whether participants were recruited from a student population. TRUE = Participants were recruited from a student population, FALSE = Participants were not recruited from a student population.

children.name: Low
children.desc: Participants have relatively low amounts of criticality in providing the public good

children.name: High
children.desc: Participants have relatively high amounts of criticalilty in providing the public good

children.name: Medium
children.desc: Participants have relatively medium amounts of criticality in providing the public good

children.name: Absent
children.desc: Baseline. A comparison to treatments that provide information that manipulate participants (objective or subjective) criticality of behavior in providing a public good

children.name: Perceived criticality
children.desc: Correlation between cooperation and subjective estimates that one's contribution is critical to providing the public good (referred to as "self-efficacy" in some studies).

children.name: High
children.desc: participants or groups are classified as displaying a high cooperative behavior

children.name: Low
children.desc: participants or groups are classified as displaying a low cooperative behavior

children.name: Medium
children.desc: participants or groups are classified as displaying a medium cooperative behavior

children.name: Low
children.desc: Other players are classified as displaying a low cooperative behavior

children.name: High
children.desc: Other players are classified as displaying a high cooperative behavior

children.name: Medium
children.desc: Other players are classified as displaying a medium cooperative behavior

children.name: Partner's behavior (correlation)
children.desc: Correlation between participant and other(s) behavior.

children.name: Participant's own behavior (correlation)
children.desc: Correlation between participant's behavior at two different time points (e.g., current trials and past trials).

children.name: Universalism
children.desc: Defining goal: understanding, appreciation, tolerance, and protection for the welfare of all people and for nature (Schwartz, 2012)

children.name: Benevolence
children.desc: Defining goal: preserving and enhancing the welfare of those with whom one is in frequent personal contact (Schwartz, 2012)

children.name: Hedonism
children.desc: Defining goal: pleasure or sensuous gratification for oneself (Schwartz, 2012)

children.name: Achievement
children.desc: Defining goal: personal success through demonstrating competence according to social standards (Schwartz, 2012)

children.name: Power
children.desc: Defining goal: social status and prestige, control or dominance over people and resources (Schwartz, 2012)

children.name: Security
children.desc: Defining goal: safety, harmony, and stability of society, of relationships, and of self (Schwartz, 2012)

children.name: Self-direction
children.desc: Defining goal: independent thought and actionâchoosing, creating, exploring (Schwartz, 2012)

children.name: Conformity
children.desc: Defining goal: restraint of actions, inclinations, and impulses likely to upset or harm others and violate social expectations or norms (Schwartz, 2012)

children.name: Stimulation
children.desc: Defining goal: excitement, novelty, and challenge in life (Schwartz, 2012)

children.name: Tradition
children.desc: Defining goal: respect, commitment, and acceptance of the customs and ideas that oneâs culture or religion provides (Schwartz, 2012)

children.name: Other values
children.desc: Values are abstract cognitive structures that indicate desirable ways of behaving in a broad range of situations (Rokeach, 1973; Schwartz, 1992).

children.name: Low
children.desc: Participants are told there is relatively low amounts of variability in group member behavior

children.name: High
children.desc: Participants are told there is relatively high amounts of variability in group member behavior

children.name: Medium
children.desc: Participants are told there is relatively medium amounts of variability in group member behavior

children.name: High Cooperation

children.name: Medium Cooperation

children.name: High

children.desc: Participants displayed medium levels of a specific hormone

children.name: career oriented
children.desc: high scoring individuals give a greater importance to the career as compared to more traditional activities (e.g., the care of the family)

children.name: low cooperation

children.name: high cooperation
children.desc: Participants are provided a suggestion to contribute a relatively high amount to the public good

children.name: High

children.desc: Low monitoring cost

children.name: None
children.desc: Free monitoring

children.desc: Ordinarily, feedback is available to players without cost. Costly monitoring refers to design in which players must pay a fee to access information, typically about the contributions of other players. TRUE = Costly monitoring, FALSE = Free monitoring.

children.name: Low
children.desc: Participants were placed at a relatively low physical distance during the game

children.name: High
children.desc: Participants were placed at a relatively high physical distance during the game

children.name: Medium
children.desc: Participants were placed at a relatively medium physical distance during the game

children.name: Real
children.desc: Participants involved in real-time interactions with real participant(s)

children.name: Hypothetical
children.desc: Participants imagined interactions with others or played with a computer

children.name: Deception
children.desc: Participants believe that they are interacting with real participants, but experimenter strategy was used

children.name: High
children.desc: High relative level of tokens participants were endowed with in the game

children.name: Low
children.desc: Low relative level of tokens participants were endowed with in the game

children.name: Medium
children.desc: Medium relative level of tokens participants were endowed with in the game

children.name: Medium
children.desc: Participants were classified as having a relative state trust

children.name: High
children.desc: Participants were classified as having a relative high state trust

children.name: Low
children.desc: Participants were classified as having a relative low state trust

children.name: State trust
children.desc: Correlation between cooperation and the extent to which participants report to trust the partner(s) in the game (expectations about others' behavior and a generalized propensity to trust are coded separately).

children.name: High
children.desc: Participants were classified as having a relative high social capital

children.name: Low
children.desc: Participants were classified as having a relative low social capital

children.name: Medium
children.desc: Participants were classified as having a relative medium social capital

children.name: Social capital
children.desc: Correlation between cooperation and individual differences in social capital measures, which capture the quality of the networks individuals are immersed in (e.g.,  volunteering, active participation in electoral process, number of friends). Although trust is defined as part of the social capital, it is currently coded separately as an individual difference (trust propensity) or state trust.

children.name: Last
children.desc: Last trial of previous block

children.name: First
children.desc: First trial of subsequent block

children.name: Low
children.desc: Participants had a low level of comprehension of the game

children.name: High
children.desc: Participants had a high level of comprehension of the game

children.name: Medium
children.desc: Participants had a medium level of comprehension of the game

children.name: Comprehension of the game
children.desc: Correlation between cooperation and the degree to which participants understood the game (Usually based on answers to comprehension questions).

children.name: Task Structure
children.desc: Task structure includes any variable that affects how the social dilemma game is implemented and how the structure of the situation varies. This group of variables includes the variables labeled as âStudy Characteristicsâ in the Ontology and in the Interface, such as: game type, conflict indices, payoff structure, MPCR, returns from the public good, provision points, experimental setting, game duration, sequentiality, choice options, matching protocols, group size, network structure, incentives, feedback, procedure, power, order effects, and manipulations of uncertainty and heterogeneity of any of the above mentioned variables.

children.name: Institutions
children.desc: Institutions includes any variable that is about rules that regulate how people interact in the dilemma. This group of variables includes the implementation of communication, punishment, reward, taxations, auctions, and voting

children.name: Country
children.desc: Country coding includes variables measured at the country/city/ethnic group level that are correlated with cooperative behavior in the social dilemma. This group of variables is only composed by country/city/ethnic group level indicators and, thus, this variable does not vary for participants from the same country country/city/ethnic group

children.name: Other
children.desc: Other coding includes any other variables that cannot be classified using any of the above-mentioned categories. Example of these variables are: game framing, priming, fmri scanner, singing, University affiliation, classifications of participants based on social categorization (e.g., job), Language of the experiment, performance in other unrelated tasks, default options, othersâ behavior and outcomes, response to strategy method

children.name: Individual Differences
children.desc: Individual differences include any variable that was measured at the individual level and on which individuals vary (e.g.,  personality traits, beliefs, attitudes, values, preferences, emotions, behavior, mood, socio-economic background, gender, age, and education)

children.name: Interactions in the Game
children.desc: Interactions in the Game includes variables that relate to the relationships between individuals interacting in the social dilemmas or the perceptions of the partner(s) based on impressions or on their behavior in the game. This group of variables includes partner strategy, anonymity, closeness, similarity, acquaintance, reputational information, content of communication, credibility of promises, information about the partner(s), eye contact, partnerâs goal, and group identification
